title: Throwback: A Time-Attacking Toyota MR2
description: For many in Japan, mid-November signals that winter is just around the corner. For a select few, however, it marks the countdown to the start of a new time attack racing season. In just a few weeks, Tsukuba Circuit will host the second HKS Hiper Challenge meet of 2024 – the first major time attack event […] The post Throwback: A Time-Attacking Toyota MR2 appeared first on Speedhunters.
author: TheSpeedhunters
excerpt: For many in Japan, mid-November signals that winter is just around the corner. For a select few, however, it marks the countdown to the start of a new time attack racing season. In just a few weeks, Tsukuba Circuit will host the second HKS Hiper Challenge meet of 2024 – the first major time attack event …
text: 2024 IntroFor many in Japan, mid-November signals that winter is just around the corner. For a select few, however, it marks the countdown to the start of a new time attack racing season. In just a few weeks, Tsukuba Circuit will host the second HKS Hiper Challenge meet of 2024 – the first major time attack event of the 2024/2025 season. If the weather holds, fast lap times on the legendary TC2000 course are all but guaranteed. While certain chassis dominate time attack racing, not all competitors follow the conventional path in personal pursuits for speed. Five years ago, Dino introduced us to a wild SW20 Toyota MR2, spotted in the pits at Attack Tsukuba. Today, we’re revisiting his 2019 spotlight feature for this week’s throwback post. 2019 FeatureI’d heard about a mysterious time attack SW20 Toyota MR2 for a while, first told about it by the guys at Pit Road M down in Hyogo-ken just south of the Kansai region, who are famous for creating wild Mitsubishi GTOs. Pit Road M were called in to help with the engine setup in a customer project put together by &G Corporation, specifically an MR2 built for grip. Like many projects, this one started as a bit of fun and progressively got more serious as the build came together. The owner and driver, ‘Samohan’ Nakajima has managed to create one of the coolest takes on an SW20 that I’ve ever seen, and it was getting a lot of attention at Attack Tsukuba 2019. The car has a one-off box fender conversion, molded in and faded into the bumper at the front, with an extended splitter/diffuser section mated up to pair of canards at each corner of the nose. It also runs extremely tall and sharp corner extensions that run out to the outermost surface of the fender, curling upwards in Super GT racer fashion. The rear fender extensions are bolted onto the underlying cut quarter panels, matching up with the substantial widening and skirt sections along its profile. There are massive openings to feed the turbocharged engine and smaller openings which are possibly used to direct air towards the rear brakes. Much like the &G Samuhan Nakajima Racing logo, the black, white and red livery is a nod to Toyota’s GRMN motorsport subsidiary. Because of this, the MR2 has a very modern feel to it, a contemporary take on an old and favorite modern-classic. Handling is courtesy of Öhlins dampers at each corner, while the deep-dish RAYS Volk Racing TE37Vs are shod in the time attack favorite – Yokohama Advan A050s. The tires measure 265/35R18 up front and 295/30R18 out the back. The aero treatment is wrapped up at the rear with a massive flat and finned carbon diffuser, which acts as an additional mounting point for the tall stays that hold up the single-plane wing. Check out those menacing twin exhausts. So, what’s been done to the mid-mounted 3S-GTE that came factory-fitted in the GT-S versions of the SW20? Quite a lot, as it turns out. The fully-tuned four-banger generates around 450hp depending on boost level, and maybe a little more once the nitrous oxide fogger you see in front of the throttle body is called upon. Given that this was the car’s first outing at Tsukuba, the 1:01.047 best lap it recorded was not a bad result. While Japan’s top-time attack cars are about 10 seconds faster, people seem to forget just how quick a 1-minute lap around Tsukuba is. I’d love to see this car evolve, and the team nails a decent setup for this demanding track. I have no doubt there is a lot of potential in this cool little time attacker. The Speedhunters Instagram: thespeedhunters Dino Dalle Carbonare Instagram: dino_dalle_carbonaredino@speedhunters.com OFFICIAL SPEEDHUNTERS SUPPLIERS
html:
2024 Intro

For many in Japan, mid-November signals that winter is just around the corner. For a select few, however, it marks the countdown to the start of a new time attack racing season. In just a few weeks, Tsukuba Circuit will host the second HKS Hiper Challenge meet of 2024 – the first major time attack event of the 2024/2025 season. If the weather holds, fast lap times on the legendary TC2000 course are all but guaranteed.

While certain chassis dominate time attack racing, not all competitors follow the conventional path in personal pursuits for speed. Five years ago, Dino introduced us to a wild SW20 Toyota MR2, spotted in the pits at Attack Tsukuba. Today, we’re revisiting his 2019 spotlight feature for this week’s throwback post.

2019 Feature

I’d heard about a mysterious time attack SW20 Toyota MR2 for a while, first told about it by the guys at Pit Road M down in Hyogo-ken just south of the Kansai region, who are famous for creating wild Mitsubishi GTOs.

Pit Road M were called in to help with the engine setup in a customer project put together by &G Corporation, specifically an MR2 built for grip. Like many projects, this one started as a bit of fun and progressively got more serious as the build came together. The owner and driver, ‘Samohan’ Nakajima has managed to create one of the coolest takes on an SW20 that I’ve ever seen, and it was getting a lot of attention at Attack Tsukuba 2019.

The car has a one-off box fender conversion, molded in and faded into the bumper at the front, with an extended splitter/diffuser section mated up to pair of canards at each corner of the nose. It also runs extremely tall and sharp corner extensions that run out to the outermost surface of the fender, curling upwards in Super GT racer fashion.

The rear fender extensions are bolted onto the underlying cut quarter panels, matching up with the substantial widening and skirt sections along its profile.

There are massive openings to feed the turbocharged engine and smaller openings which are possibly used to direct air towards the rear brakes.

Much like the &G Samuhan Nakajima Racing logo, the black, white and red livery is a nod to Toyota’s GRMN motorsport subsidiary. Because of this, the MR2 has a very modern feel to it, a contemporary take on an old and favorite modern-classic.

Handling is courtesy of Öhlins dampers at each corner, while the deep-dish RAYS Volk Racing TE37Vs are shod in the time attack favorite – Yokohama Advan A050s. The tires measure 265/35R18 up front and 295/30R18 out the back.

The aero treatment is wrapped up at the rear with a massive flat and finned carbon diffuser, which acts as an additional mounting point for the tall stays that hold up the single-plane wing. Check out those menacing twin exhausts.

So, what’s been done to the mid-mounted 3S-GTE that came factory-fitted in the GT-S versions of the SW20?

Quite a lot, as it turns out. The fully-tuned four-banger generates around 450hp depending on boost level, and maybe a little more once the nitrous oxide fogger you see in front of the throttle body is called upon.

Given that this was the car’s first outing at Tsukuba, the 1:01.047 best lap it recorded was not a bad result.

While Japan’s top-time attack cars are about 10 seconds faster, people seem to forget just how quick a 1-minute lap around Tsukuba is.

I’d love to see this car evolve, and the team nails a decent setup for this demanding track. I have no doubt there is a lot of potential in this cool little time attacker.

The Speedhunters

Dino Dalle Carbonare
